source.query: sternum to bar pull up hold muscles worked
source.raw_text:
A Sternum-to-Bar Isometric Hold, a variation of the Chest-to-Bar Pull-up, intensely activates your back (lats, rhomboids, traps), biceps, rear delts, forearms, and core (abs/obliques), holding at the top where your sternum touches the bar. This isometric (no movement) hold builds static strength and time under tension, focusing on deep mid-back engagement, scapular stability, and core bracing, making it excellent for developing pulling power for advanced calisthenics. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  
Muscles Worked (Primary & Secondary) 

• Back: Latissimus Dorsi, Rhomboids, Trapezius (upper/mid). 
• Arms: Biceps, Brachialis, Brachioradialis (forearms). 
• Shoulders: Rear Deltoids, Rotator Cuff. 
• Core: Rectus Abdominis, Transverse Abdominis, Obliques (for torso stability). [1, 2, 4, 5, 6]  

Movement Pattern & Key Focus 

1. Isometrics: The hold involves creating tension in the muscles without changing their length (no joint movement). 
2. Scapular Retraction & Depression: You're actively pulling your shoulder blades down and back (retraction) to bring the chest to the bar, engaging the mid-back. 
3. Elbow Flexion & Adduction: Biceps and lats work hard to keep the elbows bent and pulled back towards your body. 
4. Core Bracing: Your abdominals contract to prevent your lower back from arching (lumbar extension), keeping your torso stable. 
5. Time Under Tension: The goal is to hold this peak contraction for a set duration (e.g., 10-30 seconds), building strength in that specific pulling position. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 8]  

How It Differs from Regular Pull-ups 

• Increased Range of Motion (ROM): Reaching the sternum requires pulling higher than a standard pull-up. 
• Greater Mid-Back Activation: More focus on upper back and scapular control. 
• Builds Strength in a Weak Point: Strengthens the top, most challenging part of the pull-up. [2, 8]  

**Citations:**

[1] https://www.strengthlog.com/chest-to-bar/
[2] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uvk1Zdjjtz8
[3] https://www.youtube.com/shorts/jXlRRMmdHMw
[4] https://www.hevyapp.com/exercises/sternum-pull-up-gironda/
[5] https://blog.nasm.org/isometric-exercises
[6] https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9316832/
[7] https://bodyglide.com/blog/6-essential-functional-movements/
[8] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o6WyEEvWMOQ
